sec.title: Background
sec.p: Trade openness shows a positive impact on economic growth, supported by economic theory, and export diversification and economic complexity show a positive dynamic in trade openness in the world; however, a specificity is generated in South American countries. Therefore, the objective of the research is to analyse the macroeconomic determinants of trade openness in Latin American countries.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: The research approach was quantitative and explanatory using panel data methodology from the databases of the World Bank, Harvard University and the Economic Commission for Latin America and the Caribbean for the period 2000-2020.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The fixed effects panel data model showed that the variables that had a negative impact on trade openness were GDP, the economic complexity index and the logistic performance index, while the variables that had a positive impact were exports of high-tech products (a proxy for innovation), exports, imports, research and development expenditure and interregional trade in goods.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Therefore, during the analysis period of 2000-2020 in South America, based on the panel data analysis under fixed effects, a total of 8 countries had a negative impact on trade openness, and only the economies of Chile, French Guiana, and Brazil had a positive impact on trade openness; these economies are characterized by their better performance in the economic complexity index, their higher percentage of budget for research and development expenses, and their trade policies oriented towards the industrialization of their value-added products.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: In the South American region, according to data from the Economic Commission for Latin America (2021), the average growth in trade openness—used to assess the magnitude of foreign trade relative to a country’s domestic output—in Argentina reached 28% over the period 1990–2022. This measure has been volatile, with the highest levels of openness observed between 2002 and 2008, followed by a decline, ultimately reaching 31.7% in 2022.

In Bolivia, the average trade openness indicator was 60.1% over the 1990–2022 period, showing an upward trend from 1990 to 2008 and reaching 67.8% in 2022. In Brazil, the average trade openness growth reached 24.3% between 1990 and 2022, following an upward trend to reach 38.8% by 2022.

In Chile, trade openness averaged 62.4% from 1990 to 2022, reaching 75% in 2022; while in Colombia, the average for the same period was 35.3%, with an increase to 48.4% in 2022. Ecuador’s trade openness averaged 50.9%, reaching 57.7% in 2022. For Paraguay, the trade openness level was 82.8% during 1990–2022, while Peru reached 42.4% over the same period, and Uruguay reached 52.7%.

Trade liberalization has undoubtedly allowed Latin America to move beyond decades of economic stagnation. The shift in trade policy has been a key factor in the region’s development and well-being ( Herreros and Rosales, 2013; Lopez & Munoz, 2020). As Boloña (1993) held, “precisely because we are a small country in economic terms, we must diversify our markets, expand the scale of our economy, benefit from international markets to grow and accumulate capital, to overcome poverty and achieve the desired levels of well-being and prosperity” (p.13).

In this regard, Falcón (2021) points out that one of the main challenges for trade policy is to guide economies toward greater diversification of productive structures. This shift would allow countries in the region to advance toward higher economic complexity based on knowledge accumulation, moving beyond physical or labor capital alone. Such a transformation includes technological development and an evolution of the export basket toward higher value-added manufacturing, reducing dependency on commodities and generating sustainable comparative advantages. There is, therefore, a clear relationship between trade liberalization, economic complexity, innovation, research and development, and economic growth ( Lee & Lee, 2020; Shahzad et al., 2022).

In this context, the present article aims to analyze the macroeconomic determinants of trade liberalization in Latin American countries. To this end, it poses the question: What are the macroeconomic determinants of trade liberalization in Latin American countries? A panel data analysis will be employed, accounting for variables such as economic complexity, innovation, research and development, and economic growth during the period 2000–2020.

The primary contribution of this study lies in the specificity of its model, which is crucial for policymakers. By focusing exclusively on South American countries within a defined period (2000–2020), the study adds to the empirical evidence on the importance of better integration into the global economy through enhanced competitiveness. In this framework, trade liberalization is viewed as a relevant factor for income distribution and poverty reduction, promoting investment and driving international trade dynamics within the region.

The growth of international trade flows, driven by technological development and investment in R&D, has been a key factor in sustainable economic growth, especially within economies with trade liberalization policies. According to Castañeda Martínez and López González (2022) trade liberalization should promote technological diffusion and economic growth, but in some cases, such as Mexico, the expected effects do not materialize due to structural limitations. However, Grande González (2023) highlights that innovation and digitalization have significantly improved the competitiveness of developed economies, provided that appropriate regulatory frameworks are in place. In this context, economic policies aimed at trade liberalization must be accompanied by investment strategies in technological infrastructure and the strengthening of the R&D ecosystem to ensure that the benefits of trade are not concentrated in just a few sectors and economic actors ( Orquera Carranco, 2023).

Moreover, the impact of trade agreements on attracting foreign investment reinforces the relationship between trade openness and economic development. Castañeda Martínez and López González (2022) how treaties such as NAFTA have increased foreign direct investment in Mexico, strengthening its industry and economic growth. However, Orquera Carranco (2023) emphasizes that companies must play an active role in sustainable development, aligning their strategies with the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) to ensure equitable economic growth. In this regard, Castañeda Martínez and López González (2022) highlight the role of international organizations, such as the OECD, in promoting free trade and fiscal regulation, though challenges remain regarding the fairness of global governance. Thus, trade liberalization will only be effective in terms of sustainability if complemented by policies that strengthen technology, incentivize research, and promote inclusive development strategies.

However, a knowledge gap remains regarding the specific macroeconomic determinants influencing trade liberalization in Latin America. Despite evidence suggesting that factors like economic complexity and innovation play significant roles, it is not entirely clear how these factors interact with other structural and political aspects unique to the region. This study seeks to address that gap by providing a detailed analysis that can serve as a foundation for more effective public policy formulation across the region.

sec.title: 2. Literature review
sec.p: In the international context, Wang et al. (2023) conduct a study evaluating economic complexity, trade diversification, renewable energy consumption, and environmental taxes as drivers of growth from 1995 to 2018. The findings indicate that these factors significantly promoted growth in BRICTS countries, with relevant policy implications for achieving marginal contributions to economic development. Similarly, Li and Rigby (2023) find a positive and significant relationship between economic growth and complex technological diversification in China, specifically in 1991-1995 and 2011-2015. Here, knowledge complexity and smart specialization demonstrate a knowledge development pathway toward achieving regional competitive advantage.

A panel VAR analysis across 11 European countries (2001-2016) reveals a unidirectional relationship between economic growth and financial development, and between trade and economic growth, but a negative association between innovation and economic growth, as well as between trade and innovation ( Mtar & Belazreg, 2023). This suggests that each country’s role depends on innovation and productivity, and recommends that institutional quality is essential for improving trade regulation and fostering innovation in local companies to mitigate the effects of trade liberalization.

Various studies demonstrate relationships between economic complexity, innovation, research and development, and economic growth. In 28 African countries (1995-2019), analysis shows how economic complexity moderates the impact of natural resources on economic growth in both the short and long term, proposing policies to effectively link these factors ( Mesagan & Vo, 2023). In Russia, the creation of high-tech products and markets is viewed as essential for long-term economic development, where technological diversification in high-tech sectors drives competitiveness and market expansion ( Goryushkin & Khalimova, 2023).

While Mesquita and Stein (2019) they consider that although the great trade liberalization in Latin America has led to a positive impact on economic growth and well-being being the channel that helped recover much of the economies of Latin America from their participation in trade in the gross domestic product in the region that reached 28% they still face challenges in terms of technological aspect and innovation to continue the solid growth of international trade; this because there are comparative advantages that allow productivity leaps ( Llanos & Brown, 2021; Vela et al., 2021).

For Chávez (2021) considers in the panel data model two related equations innovation as the dependent variable and trade openness as the independent variable and as a second equation was obtained as the dependent variable to the predictions of innovation and trade openness as the explanatory variable.

Meanwhile, Fusco et al. (2020) considers in their analysis of dynamic panel data where they analyze food security and trade openness developing three regression equations with indicators of trade openness, tariffs, and globalization. While Cetin et al. (2018) considers economic growth, energy consumption, trade openness, and financial development as explanatory variables and carbon emissions as the dependent variable for the case of Turkey.

sec.title: 3.1 Trade openness
sec.p: Gräbner et al. (2021) believe that international trade generates economic growth, suggesting that while trade openness is not a direct or robust determinant in economic growth, it contributes significantly to it. By leveraging growth potential, greater trade openness generates ideas and knowledge, along with their respective technical advancements, to open up new goods and services in international trade, contributing from the theory of the openness paradigm and initiating a debate on the causality of growth ( Silajdzic et al., 2018).

sec.title: 3.2 Economic growth
sec.p: Hartmann (2014) from the contribution of economic theory, considers that growth is linked to the increase in production, income, and consumption. Meanwhile, the classic view of Smith (1976) considers that both the division of labor and trade are key aspects to achieving growth, explained by the classical factors of capital, labor, and land, but with an additional factor related to technology ( Solow, 1956). Subsequently, approaches to economic growth explained by technological progress emerged, providing a different perspective on long-term growth ( Romer, 1986) with technology as an exogenous factor of growth rather than an endogenous one.

sec.title: 3.3 Economic complexity
sec.p: Hausmann et al. (2020) consider the theory of economic complexity, which involves moving away from traditional factors to focus on knowledge as the main value generator for achieving a new structural transformation that allows diversifying the productive matrix and empowering the aspect of greater competitiveness. For Hidalgo and Hausmann (2009) economic complexity refers to the set of a region’s export products that shows a country’s productive capacity based on existing capabilities and know-how, implying that the more diverse and value-added the export products, the more productive the region is considered.

sec.title: 3.4 Innovation
sec.p: The paradigm of innovation and structural changes have become prominent in recent literature due to the composition of new economic systems where creation, innovation, and entrepreneurship have led to major changes in countries like India, China, and the United States, whose knowledge-based growth has led to their exponential development. Schumpeter (1941) in his theory of economic development addressed that innovation, as well as inventions by scientists, would lead to creating entirely new investment, growth, and employment opportunities. According to Schumpeter and Swedberg (2003) the innovation process can be divided into four dimensions: invention, innovation, diffusion, and imitation.

sec.title: 3.5 Research and development
sec.p: Elfaki and Ahmed (2024) consider that as a result of technological adoption, these elements are fundamental for the economic growth of any nation. In a world where global competition is increasingly intense, the ability to innovate and continuously improve becomes a determining factor for economic success. R&D drives progress, not only through the creation of new products and services but also by optimizing existing processes, thus increasing productivity and efficiency across various industries.

Companies that allocate resources to research and development tend to be at the forefront of creating novel products and services that better meet consumer needs. This not only makes them more competitive but also enables the creation of new industries and markets, which in turn can lead to sustained economic growth.
Being the hypothesis that economic complexity, innovation, research and development, and economic growth are the determinants of trade openness.

sec.title: 4.1 Methodological design
sec.p: A quantitative approach is considered, with a type of explanatory research that corresponds to identifying the impact of economic complexity, innovation, research and development, and economic growth on the trade openness of South American countries during the period 2000-2020.

The variables analyzed have not been modified, and the research is a non-experimental design; therefore, it has been verified that it was conducted in a specific context of the South American countries and the interaction of the unmanipulated variables ( Hernández et al., 2018).

The use of a panel data model in this research is statistically robust and methodologically relevant for several reasons. First, this approach allows for controlling unobservable heterogeneity among the South American countries analyzed, which is crucial since each country has unique characteristics that may influence trade openness, such as institutional, cultural, or geographical differences. By incorporating fixed or random effects, the panel model minimizes bias due to omitted variables, improving the accuracy of estimates.

sec.title: 4.2 Population and sampling
sec.p: The population involves a total of 2079 data points across 9 analyzed variables considering a total of 11 South American countries, noting that we have 231 data points per variable for each country under analysis during the 2000-2020 period.

The sample is equal to the population and comprises a total of 2079 data points across 9 analyzed variables considering a total of 11 South American countries, noting that we have 231 data points per variable for each country under analysis during the 2000-2020 period.
The unit of analysis consists of each South American country, involving a total of 11 countries analyzed during the 2000-2020 period.

sec.title: 4.3 Data collection technique and procedure
sec.p: For measuring the variables, documentary analysis was used as the technique, and the observation guide served as the instrument, which is a tool used to collect data systematically and structured during an observation or study.

The data obtained from the World Bank corresponded to the explanatory variables of gross domestic product, imports, exports, high-tech product exports, research and development expenditure, and the logistics performance index; as well as from the Harvard University Economic Complexity Atlas, where information on the economic complexity index was obtained. Regarding the interregional trade of goods variable, it was obtained from the database of the Economic Commission for Latin America and the Caribbean during the mentioned analysis period.

A panel data model is used, where from this model, the impact of economic complexity, innovation, research and development, and economic growth on the trade openness of the South American countries during the 2000-2020 period is quantified. To perform the estimates consistently and achieve a proper analysis, the variables have been transformed into logarithms such as gross domestic product, imports, exports, high-tech product exports, and total interregional trade of goods.

sec.title: 4.4 Data analysis
sec.p: The databases used for this research stem from international institutions such as the World Bank, Harvard University, and the Economic Commission for Latin America for the period 2000-2020.

On the other hand, the incorporation of the variable’s economic complexity (eco-nomic complexity index), innovation (proxy: exports of high-tech products), research and development (percentage expenditure on research and development), the logistic performance index, and total interregional trade of goods are evidenced in the following equation:
ACi,t=Bo+B1(Exporti,t)+B2(Importi,t)+B3(Pbii,t)+B4(ICEi,t)+B5(Export_teci,t)+B6(i_di,t)+B7(i_logi,t)+B8(c_interi,t)+ei,t (2)

Furthermore, to choose between a fixed or random effects model, the Hausman test (1978) (as cited in Onali et al., 2017) is utilized.

sec.title: 4.3 Ethical considerations
sec.p: The data for this study were obtained from international institutions such as the World Bank, Harvard University and the Economic Commission for Latin America for the period 2000-2020. Access to the data is public and free of charge on the detailed websites and adheres to rigorous ethical standards to protect the confidentiality of the published data.

In addition, the data from the World Bank, Harvard University and the Economic Commission for Latin America is an effort by international institutions to generate databases that allow interaction with public policy makers.

Although we cannot provide specific details on the process of obtaining the data, it is imperative to indicate that, as prestigious governmental institutions such as the World Bank, Harvard University and the Economic Commission for Latin America, there is a use and policies to access under ethical practices in the generation of data in the respective public repositories and free access and obtaining informed consent.

For the ethical use of public data obtained by the World Bank, Harvard University and the Economic Commission for Latin America, we adhere to the principles of intellectual honesty, truthfulness, transparency, human integrity, respect for intellectual property, justice and responsibility, the study aims to comply with the “Code of Ethics in Research of the Universidad César Vallejo, version 01; by Resolution of the University Council N° 0340-2021-UCV”, code of ethics that was used throughout the development of the scientific article, since as main author we work all scientific activity respecting the code of ethics of the UCV university.

We have used the data from the described repositories for research purposes only, as permitted by the conditions of use by the World Bank, Harvard University and the Economic Commission for Latin America. We have not attempted to modify any data, and our analysis does not include any personally identifiable information.

By using publicly available anonymized data and adhering to ethical principles in our research, we aim to minimize any potential ethical issues while leveraging valuable information for the benefit of research in economic science.

sec.title: 5. Results
sec.p:
The research utilizes data sourced from the World Bank, Harvard University, and the Economic Commission for Latin America and the Caribbean. Descriptive statistics for each variable analyzed are presented in
Table 2, including the mean, standard deviation, minimum, maximum, skewness, and kurtosis. Additionally, the correlation matrix between the variables under analysis is provided. It shows that exports, imports, gross domestic product (GDP), the economic complexity index, total interregional trade of goods, and research and development had a negative relationship with trade openness, whereas the export of high-technology products and the logistics performance index had a positive correlation with trade openness during the period 2000-2020. The negative relationship indicates that South American countries, except for Chile and Brazil, have shown less trade openness in their economies over the last decade with respect to the international market. According to the Economic Commission for Latin America (2021) economies in South America have demonstrated reduced trade openness due to the slowdown in international trade despite their high dependence on imports and extensive trade relations with major global economic powers in a scenario of economic uncertainty and a political shift to the left, which helps to understand which variables are influencing reduced trade openness (
Figure 2).

sec.p: To determine the best model (fixed or random effects), the Hausman Test is used, which compares the beta coefficients obtained through the fixed and random effects estimators, identifying whether the differences between them are significant. In both cases, the weight matrix is homoscedastic. Thus, considering that the Prob > Chi 2 is less than 5%, the fixed effects model is employed, which shows a higher global significance of 94.5%.

The interpretation of the fixed effects details that for every 1% increase in the exports of high-technology products, trade openness increased by 0.05%. Similarly, a 1% increase in exports raises trade openness by 0.30%; a 1% increase in imports leads to a 0.09% increase in trade openness; a 1% increase in total interregional trade of goods increases trade openness by 0.005%; and a 1% increase in spending on research and development results in a 0.14% increase in trade openness. Regarding gross domestic product, a 1% increase led to a 0.42% decrease in trade openness. For the economic complexity index, a 1% increase resulted in a 0.08% decrease in trade openness, and for the logistics performance index, a 1% increase led to a 0.13% decrease in trade openness during the analysis period 2000-2020.

These findings provide valuable insights into the factors that influence trade openness in South American countries, highlighting the complex interplay between various economic and logistical variables. The results underscore the importance of considering both economic structures and policy environments when assessing the openness of trade regimes.

sec.title: 6. Discussion
sec.p: The impact of economic complexity, innovation, research and development, and economic growth on the trade openness of South American countries in the period 2000-2020 shows a differential behavior. These countries have exhibited lower trade openness in their economies over the last decade compared to the international market. Additionally, there is a reduced economic complexity due to lower diversification of productive matrices in export baskets, resulting in economies still heavily reliant on commodities or primary export products.

The greatest decline in trade openness is observed in Venezuela, with a negative impact of 104%. This is attributed to the country’s current economic crisis characterized by inflation and high prices of its oil commodity, coupled with a closed economy model. Among the remaining market economy countries, negative impacts are noted in Peru (15%), Ecuador (16%), Argentina (16%), Uruguay (10%), Bolivia had the greatest decline in Trade Openness at 18%, Ecuador and Argentina had 16%, Colombia had 13%, and Paraguay had 10%; these declines were due to diminishing returns and the accumulation of physical capital. Conversely, Chile, French Guiana, and Brazil have experienced positive impacts of 12%, 31%, and 25%, respectively. These economies are characterized by better performance in the economic complexity index, higher percentage of budget allocated to research and development expenses, and trade policies focused on industrializing value-added products such as high-tech products (
Figure 3).

sec.p: These results align with the findings of the Economic Commission for Latin America and the Caribbean, which has shown that economies in South America have exhibited lower trade openness due to the slowdown in international trade. Countries such as Peru, Ecuador, Bolivia, Chile, Colombia, Paraguay, and Venezuela have relied on their primary sector as the backbone of their export industry ( Economic Commission for Latin America, 2021).

Venezuela muestra datos atípicos en el análisis de apertura comercial debido a su profunda crisis económica y su modelo de economía cerrada. A diferencia de otros países sudamericanos, Venezuela experimentó una caída del 104% en su apertura comercial, la más pronunciada en la región. Este comportamiento se explica por su dependencia extrema del petróleo como principal commodity, combinada con una inflación descontrolada y políticas económicas que han limitado la diversificación productiva y la integración con mercados internacionales. Mientras otros países, como Chile y Brasil, han logrado impactos positivos gracias a una mayor complejidad económica y políticas orientadas a la industrialización y la innovación, Venezuela ha visto un retroceso significativo en su capacidad para competir en el mercado global. Esta situación resalta la importancia de políticas comerciales y económicas que fomenten la diversificación y la inversión en investigación y desarrollo para evitar la vulnerabilidad asociada a la dependencia de recursos primarios.

Furthermore, these results are consistent with the findings of Mesquita Moreira and Stein (2019), who found that while significant trade liberalization in Latin America has led to a positive impact on economic growth, challenges remain in terms of technological aspects and innovation to sustain solid international trade growth. There are still comparative advantages that allow for productivity leaps, yet South American countries have not yet taken off in terms of innovation and thus achieving higher productivity.

Corrales Sillo (2021) and Mesquita Moreira and Stein (2019) also suggest that the aforementioned results indicate that South American economies still lack knowledge accumulation, which translates into a lack of innovation. To address this, policies focusing on innovation and development are needed to add more value to export products and access larger markets, thereby enhancing competitiveness. These economies are characterized by diminishing returns due to the accumulation of physical capital.

sec.title: 7. Conclusions
sec.p: In the analysis period of 2000-2020, South American countries exhibited differential behavior as they showed lower trade openness in their economies compared to the international market. Additionally, there was lower economic complexity due to less diversification in export baskets, resulting in economies still based on commodities or primary export products.

Based on panel data analysis using fixed effects, a total of 8 countries—Peru, Ecuador, Argentina, Uruguay, Bolivia, Colombia, Paraguay, and Venezuela—experienced a negative impact on trade openness. Only the economies of Chile, French Guiana, and Brazil showed a positive impact on trade openness, characterized by better performance in economic complexity indices. These countries allocate a higher percentage of their budget to research and development and pursue trade policies aimed at industrializing products with added value.

Interpretation of fixed effects reveals that the variables with the greatest impact on trade openness during 2000-2020 were gross domestic product, logistics performance index, economic complexity index, exports, imports, and research and development expenditure.

While significant trade liberalization in Latin America has led to a positive impact on economic growth, challenges remain in terms of technological aspects and innovation to sustain solid international trade growth. South American countries still struggle to innovate and achieve higher productivity, facing a slowdown in international trade despite high dependence on imports and extensive trade relations with major global economic powers amidst economic uncertainty and a shift towards left-wing political systems.

For South American countries, it is recommended to strengthen policies that promote investment in research and development to drive innovation, as well as enhance education in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics to foster creative industries that add value to primary export products.

Developing strategic investment planning for infrastructure such as roads, ports, airports, and information technologies is essential to improve connectivity and facilitate the transportation of goods and services, thereby boosting energy efficiency and reducing logistical production costs.

Identifying the positive effect of trade liberalization on economic growth in Latin American countries, albeit unsustainable, calls for the development of clusters as a key strategy to foster competitiveness and specialization in specific sectors of the economy. This could be accompanied by fiscal and financial incentive programs to encourage investment in research and development, as well as the establishment of industrial parks, shared laboratories, and innovation centers to optimize connectivity and logistics.

The results of the panel data analysis for the period 2000–2020 reveal that trade openness in South American countries is influenced by factors such as economic complexity, innovation, research and development (R&D) spending, and economic growth. However, the findings show that most countries in the region have experienced a decline in trade openness, with the exception of Chile, Brazil, and French Guiana, which have maintained a positive impact thanks to policies focused on industrialization and export diversification. In this context, it is crucial to propose specific policy recommendations tailored to each country's realities to strengthen their integration into the global market and promote sustainable economic growth.

p.bold: a. Promotion of Research and Development (R&D):

list-item.p: Chile and Brazil: Both countries have demonstrated outstanding performance in R&D, contributing to greater trade openness. It is recommended to continue strengthening tax incentives for companies investing in innovation, as well as increasing collaboration between universities, research centers, and the private sector. Competitive grant programs for R&D projects and the creation of technology parks could further expand their impact.

Argentina and Uruguay: These countries have a solid scientific foundation but require greater investment in R&D. Policies should encourage technology transfer from academic sectors to industry and the creation of specialized technology clusters in sectors such as biotechnology and agribusiness.

Peru, Ecuador, and Bolivia: With economies still dependent on commodities, it is essential to diversify R&D investment into higher value-added sectors. Training programs in advanced technologies and the creation of public funds to finance innovation projects in small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) could be effective strategies.

Colombia and Paraguay: Both countries face transportation infrastructure challenges that limit their ability to integrate into global value chains. Investment should be prioritized in logistics corridors connecting ports, airports, and production centers, as well as modernizing customs procedures to streamline international trade.

Venezuela: Given its economic crisis, the urgent rehabilitation of basic infrastructure, such as roads and ports, is necessary with the support of international organizations. Technical and financial cooperation programs could facilitate the reconstruction of its logistical capacity.

Chile and Brazil: These countries have successfully diversified their exports into high-tech products. It is recommended to continue promoting sectors such as sustainable mining, renewable energy, and advanced manufacturing through tax incentives and access to international markets.

Argentina and Uruguay: With a strong agro-industrial base, these countries could diversify into organic and niche products, capitalizing on growing global demand. Certification policies and international promotion efforts would be key.

Peru, Ecuador, and Bolivia: Reducing dependence on commodities is crucial by promoting sectors such as tourism, non-traditional agro-exports, and light manufacturing. Training programs in business management and access to financing for exporting SMEs could be decisive.

p.bold: d. Strengthening Education in Science and Technology:

list-item.p: All countries: The development of specialized human capital is essential to drive innovation and competitiveness. It is recommended to increase investment in STEM education (science, technology, engineering, and mathematics) and promote partnerships between educational institutions and the productive sector to ensure that academic programs align with labor market needs.

p.bold: e. Creation of Clusters and Industrial Parks:

list-item.p: Chile, Brazil, and Argentina: These countries could lead the creation of industrial clusters specialized in sectors such as green mining, biotechnology, and Industry 4.0. Public-private collaboration and attracting foreign direct investment (FDI) would be key to their success.
Peru, Ecuador, and Bolivia: The formation of clusters in sectors such as agribusiness and tourism could generate economies of scale and improve international competitiveness.

sec.p: In conclusion, the implementation of these specific recommendations, tailored to each country's realities, would not only enhance trade openness but also promote sustainable and diversified economic growth in the region. Collaboration between governments, the private sector, and international organizations will be key to achieving these goals.

body.p:
I have carefully reviewed the revised version of the article "The Macroeconomic Determinants of Trade Openness in Latin American Countries: A Panel Data Analysis." The authors have made significant improvements to the manuscript in response to my previous feedback, as well as the suggestions provided by the other peer reviewers. Below is an assessment of the key revisions:
Introduction:
The authors have enhanced the coherence and clarity of the introduction, making it easier to follow. The study gap has been more explicitly defined, which helps the reader better understand the context and rationale of the research.
Literature Review:
The literature review has been substantially improved, adopting a more scholarly tone and clearer structure. The authors have separated the literature review from the theoretical foundations, ensuring better readability and organization.
Methodology:
The methodology section has been revised by merging subheadings, as per the reviewers' suggestions. This change contributes to a more streamlined and cohesive presentation of the research design and approach.
Results Section:
The results section has been rewritten to improve the clarity of the statistical tests and the presentation of findings. The authors have provided more in-depth discussion and interpretation of the results, which enhances the value of the analysis.
Addressing Reviewer Observations:
The authors have addressed the 50 observations raised in the original peer review, demonstrating a thorough and comprehensive revision process. These revisions have led to a more polished manuscript with greater academic rigor.
Evaluation and Conclusion:

The revised manuscript now exhibits improved clarity, structure, and academic quality. The authors have successfully addressed the concerns raised during the peer review process, resulting in a more well-rounded and rigorous paper.
Given the improvements made, I believe that the article is now suitable for indexing. I am therefore happy to approve the revised version of the manuscript.

body.p: The article explores the impact of economic complexity, innovation, R&D, and industrial policies on trade openness in South America from 2000 to 2020. Using fixed-effects panel data analysis, the study identifies key challenges to trade openness, including limited diversification and insufficient innovation. The findings highlight the positive effects of R&D investment in countries like Chile and Brazil, while emphasizing the need for value-added industries and sustainable policies to enhance growth (Hausmann et al., 2007).

The article is generally well-written and clear. However, the citation of current literature is limited. Studies published after 2020 should be included to provide a broader context, especially regarding post-pandemic economic trends.

p.bold: Appropriateness of Study Design and Technical Soundness

body.p: The study design and methodology are appropriate for the research objectives. The use of fixed-effects panel analysis effectively captures variations across countries and time. However, a more in-depth discussion of the robustness of the model would strengthen the technical soundness of the analysis.

While the methods are described, there is insufficient detail for full replication. The data sources and variable definitions should be elaborated further. Additionally, the econometric model's assumptions and diagnostic checks need to be explicitly stated.

The statistical analysis is robust and the interpretation of findings is mostly sound. However, more nuanced discussion is needed for outliers like Venezuela, where political instability has likely influenced the results.
The study references reliable data sources but does not provide direct access to datasets or processing details. Publishing or linking these materials would improve transparency.

The conclusions align with the results, but the recommendations could be more specific. For instance, suggesting targeted policies for fostering R&D, improving infrastructure, or diversifying exports in each country would enhance their practical relevance.

list-item.p: Update the literature review with recent studies, especially those covering the post-2020 period.
Provide detailed descriptions of data processing, variable definitions, and econometric models to enhance reproducibility.
Make datasets and analysis scripts publicly available to improve transparency and future research opportunities.
Expand the discussion on country-specific findings, particularly for outliers like Venezuela, which may distort the regional analysis.
Strengthen the policy recommendations by tailoring them to individual country contexts with actionable strategies.

list-item.p: The abstract outlines the study's aims and provides a snapshot of the results. However, it lacks sufficient detail about the methodological approach and the numerical outcomes. Explicitly mention key quantitative findings, such as the percentage changes in trade openness associated with specific variables, to enhance its clarity and appeal.

The introduction provides a thorough context regarding trade liberalization in Latin America, but the central research problem could be articulated more succinctly. Clarify how the study addresses specific gaps in the literature and its unique contribution compared to prior studies.

The literature review is comprehensive but somewhat dense. Consider organizing it thematically, focusing on key determinants of trade openness (e.g., economic complexity, innovation) and their relevance to the Latin American context. This restructuring will improve readability and flow.

The methodology section is detailed but could better justify the choice of the fixed-effects model. Explain why this model was preferred over random effects or alternative econometric techniques in addressing the study's research questions.

The use of panel data is appropriate for this study, but the choice of the time period (2000–2020) requires further justification. Discuss why this specific timeframe was selected and how it influences the study's applicability to current trade policy challenges.

The explanation of the econometric models is technically sound, but it would benefit from more intuitive explanations for non-specialist readers. For instance, provide a brief overview of how the Generalized Least Squares (GLS) model addresses heteroscedasticity and autocorrelation.

The study's reliance on publicly available data is a strength, but the manuscript should clarify potential limitations related to data quality or coverage. For example, discuss any challenges in capturing informal trade flows, which are significant in some Latin American economies.

The descriptive statistics section provides useful insights, but the discussion of key trends is underdeveloped. Highlight notable patterns, such as variations in trade openness across countries, and their potential implications.

The results section identifies significant variables affecting trade openness but does not adequately explore country-specific dynamics. For instance, why do Chile and Brazil perform better in terms of economic complexity compared to other countries in the region?

The discussion section effectively connects findings to existing literature but could delve deeper into the implications of negative relationships, such as those between GDP and trade openness. How might these results inform regional trade policies or economic strategies?

The manuscript notes that the economic complexity index negatively affects trade openness but does not sufficiently explore why this counterintuitive relationship exists. Consider integrating qualitative insights or case studies to provide a more nuanced explanation.

While the focus on South America is justified, the manuscript could benefit from a brief comparison with other regions to contextualize the findings. For example, how do the determinants of trade openness in Latin America differ from those in Asia or Africa?

The manuscript mentions that certain countries exhibit declining trade openness due to a lack of diversification in export baskets. Expanding this analysis with specific examples, such as Venezuela's reliance on oil exports, would enhance the discussion.

The policy recommendations are relevant but somewhat general. Provide specific actions that countries could take, such as investing in high-tech export industries or improving logistics infrastructure, to enhance trade openness.

The tables and figures are informative but could be better integrated into the text. For instance, directly reference key values or trends from the descriptive statistics table when discussing results to improve coherence.

The regression results indicate that research and development expenditure positively impacts trade openness, but this finding is not sufficiently elaborated upon. Discuss how R&D investments could be incentivized in resource-dependent economies.

The manuscript uses the logistics performance index as an explanatory variable, which is innovative. However, it does not fully address why this index negatively correlates with trade openness. Explore possible reasons, such as inefficiencies in logistics systems or methodological issues.

The theoretical framework section is robust but could benefit from a conceptual diagram. Visualizing the relationships between economic complexity, innovation, and trade openness would make the study's theoretical underpinnings more accessible.
The discussion of trade openness trends could be enriched by considering external shocks, such as the global financial crisis or the COVID-19 pandemic, and their impacts on the study period.

The manuscript concludes by highlighting the importance of innovation and industrialization but does not adequately address the political and institutional barriers that might hinder these processes. Include a discussion on governance or institutional quality.

The use of econometric terminology is precise but may be challenging for readers unfamiliar with the field. Consider adding a glossary or briefly defining terms like "heteroscedasticity" and "autocorrelation" in the methodology section.
The manuscript references several influential studies but could incorporate more recent research on trade openness and economic complexity, particularly studies published after 2020.

While the conclusions are aligned with the findings, they could be more forward-looking. Suggest avenues for future research, such as examining the role of digital trade or regional trade agreements in shaping trade openness.
The ethical considerations section is clear but could explicitly address any potential biases in data collection or analysis. This would strengthen the study's credibility.
The language is generally clear, but there are instances of verbosity. Streamline sentences for clarity and impact, particularly in the introduction and literature review.
The manuscript does not address the role of human capital in trade openness, despite its potential relevance. Discuss whether factors like education levels or workforce skills influence the results.

The choice of explanatory variables is appropriate, but the manuscript could discuss alternative variables that might also affect trade openness, such as exchange rate volatility or foreign direct investment.

The manuscript identifies a positive relationship between exports of high-tech products and trade openness but does not explore the underlying mechanisms. For example, how do high-tech exports foster trade liberalization?

The discussion section mentions diminishing returns to physical capital but does not elaborate on how this affects long-term trade openness. Expanding this point would provide a more comprehensive analysis.

The study notes that some countries exhibit lower trade openness due to political shifts but does not provide detailed examples. Include specific instances of how political changes have influenced trade policies in the region.

The manuscript cites several classical economic theories but does not explicitly link them to the findings. For instance, how does the Solow growth model relate to the observed impacts of innovation and R&D?

The results highlight the role of imports in promoting trade openness, but the manuscript does not discuss the quality or composition of imports. Are certain types of imports (e.g., capital goods) more influential?
The study's focus on South America is justified, but the manuscript could explore whether its findings are applicable to other regions with similar economic structures.

The manuscript notes that trade openness has declined in some countries due to economic crises but does not address how these crises could be mitigated. Provide policy recommendations to address economic vulnerability.
The regression results are robust, but the manuscript could include additional diagnostics, such as tests for multicollinearity, to strengthen the validity of the findings.
The study's emphasis on innovation is commendable, but the manuscript could discuss the role of intellectual property rights or patent systems in fostering innovation.

The manuscript does not explore the environmental implications of trade openness, despite its relevance to sustainable development. Include a brief discussion on how trade policies could align with environmental goals.
The conclusion mentions that trade openness fosters economic growth but does not discuss the potential trade-offs, such as income inequality or labor market disruptions.
The manuscript could benefit from a stronger narrative thread connecting the introduction, methodology, results, and discussion. Ensure that each section builds logically on the previous one.
The literature review cites numerous studies but could include more critical evaluations of their methodologies or findings to highlight the study's unique contributions.
The manuscript does not address the potential role of digital technologies, such as e-commerce platforms, in influencing trade openness. Discuss their relevance, especially in the post-pandemic era.
The policy recommendations are insightful but could be supplemented with examples of successful trade policies from other regions.
The manuscript could include a sensitivity analysis to test the robustness of the regression results under different model specifications.
The findings suggest that countries with higher economic complexity exhibit greater trade openness, but the manuscript does not discuss how complexity can be enhanced in less developed economies.
The study focuses on macroeconomic variables but does not consider microeconomic factors, such as firm-level competitiveness or supply chain efficiency. Discuss their potential relevance.
The manuscript uses the Breusch-Pagan and Wooldridge tests effectively but does not explain their implications for model selection. Provide more detail on why these tests were necessary.
The conclusion could be enhanced by discussing the broader implications of the findings for global trade policies, particularly in the context of South-South cooperation.
The manuscript identifies significant country-specific differences in trade openness but does not explore potential regional collaborations to address shared challenges.
The study's emphasis on research and development is valuable, but the manuscript could discuss the role of public-private partnerships in fostering innovation.
The manuscript could benefit from professional proofreading to address minor grammatical errors and improve readability.

body.p:
1.The statement at the introduction section such as
‘Trade openness in countries around the world has shown significant relevance in addressing one of the greatest global crises, where the acute and real problem of global food security, coupled with rising inflation, demonstrates that trade policies not only ensure adequate access to food but also compel a consideration of the link with economic complexity, which in turn requires research and development and the creation of an innovation climate that impacts economic growth (Bardi & Hfaiedh, 2021; Fusco et al., 2020; Gallego & Zofío, 2018; Tabash et al., 2022)’ .
The statement is too long which ends up distorting what the researchers are trying to communicate. I suggest that the authors make it brief.

2. I suggest that authors improve on the flow of the write-up and how the various paragraphs under the introduction section are connected to make much more sense. There is a lack of coherence in the introductory section which makes it difficult to understand what the authors are trying to send around.
3. In terms of the study gap identified, authors should bring into perspective what has already been done in the study areas and what this particular study seeks to address as a gap.

4. The same can be said about the literature section of the study. The authors failed to connect the various scholars' work to make the section more coherent and interesting. Although authors made use of current research work by scholars the literature strand depicts a write-up of other researchers' work put into paragraphs. I suggest that the authors improve on the literature section of the study.
5. I suggest that authors classify the literature section into empirical and theoretical study

6. I suggest authors move the discussion of the variables under study from the theoretical basis section to theoretical study under a subheading named conceptual terms. At the same time, 3.1 and 3.2 are under the subheading ‘study theories’.
7. I suggest authors merge the following subheadings and put them under these subheadings title:
Merge 4.1.1 & 4.1.2 as 4.1 Research design
Merge 4.1.3, 4.1.4 & 4.1.5 as 4.2 Population and sampling
Merge 4.1.6 & 4.1.7 as 4.3 Data collection technique & procedure

8. Since the authors’ analysis is based on a panel dataset, I expected them to perform certain fundamental or preliminary tests, such as the cross-sectional dependency test, unit root test, and cointegration test. I suggest that the authors perform these basic tests and discuss them in the results section while describing them in the methods section.
9. Proofreading the work would help.
